data.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The introduction of high-throughput chromosome conformation capture (Hi-C) into metagenomics enables reconstructing high-quality metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) from microbial communities. Despite recent advances in recovering eukaryotic, bacterial, and archaeal genomes using Hi-C contact maps, few of Hi-C-based methods are designed to retrieve viral genomes. Here we introduce ViralCC, a publicly available tool to recover complete viral genomes and detect virus-host pairs using Hi-C data. Compared to other Hi-C-based methods, ViralCC leverages the virus-host proximity structure as a complementary information source for the Hi-C interactions. Using mock and real metagenomic Hi-C datasets from several different microbial ecosystems, including the human gut, cow fecal, and wastewater, we demonstrate that ViralCC outperforms existing Hi-C-based binning methods as well as state-of-the-art tools specifically dedicated to metagenomic viral binning. ViralCC can also reveal the taxonomic structure of viruses and virus-host pairs in microbial communities. When applied to a real wastewater metagenomic Hi-C dataset, ViralCC constructs a phage-host network, which is further validated using CRISPR spacer analyses. ViralCC is an open-source pipeline available at<jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://github.com/dyxstat/ViralCC">https://github.com/dyxstat/ViralCC</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p>
title: ViralCC retrieves complete viral genomes and virus-host pairs from metagenomic Hi-C data

assertion.name: Ethics

data.abstract: This chapter considers the clinical virology laboratory and reviews the use of virus genome detection for clinical diagnosis, which has increased dramatically. In general, virus genome detection is more rapid and sensitive than cell-culture and can be used before a detectable antibody response has developed. The chapter traces the discovery of potent antivirals for hepatitis C, hepatitis B, HIV, and influenza, wherein there is a huge demand for the diagnostic laboratory to monitor levels of virus in the appropriate clinical sample of the patient using rapid molecular tests. These tests can also give the first indication of drug-resistant virus mutants, which could compromise antiviral therapy. The chapter covers the collection and transport of clinical specimens to the laboratory, different rapid diagnostic methods, the isolation of viruses in cell cultures, and the detection of antiviral antibodies.
title: The clinical virology laboratory
